Spotlight On...RHODES

21/04/2015

Lily Papworth talks touring friendships, childhood obsessions and the art of musical intimacy with the latest singer-songwriter poised for imminent acclaim

Image by

By undefined undefined

Having finished his biggest solo UK tour to date and currently in the process of finishing his debut album, RHODES is keeping himself busy. Already with popular singles such as 'Breathe' and a new single, 'Turning Back Around', being released towards the end of the month, this fresh new talent is certainly one to keep an eye on. I managed to catch up with him at the start of his tour to find out what was to be expected. Perhaps not yet a renowned headline artist, it is still fair to say that RHODES has done the rounds. Having toured with the likes of Sam Smith, London Grammar, Ben Howard and Nick Mulvey, he certainly knows the ropes. Nevertheless, he was still excited about his own solo tour. "It's been a long time coming," he told me, "I can't wait to get out on the road now." Although song-writing is something that RHODES enjoys, touring always feels easy. "The playing live bit has got to be the least stressful part - you've got the song, it's finished and you're just performing and being out there playing for people. Then again, I do find it quite hard getting on stage every night. Being up there on your own is actually quite hard to do every day. Maybe with a band it might be nicer, you know, having a little gang on stage to play off of - I'm looking forward to that." [caption id="attachment_121323" align="alignright" width="361"] Nevertheless, song-writing is still something close to his heart. "[I love] seeing how a song you wrote in your bedroom can evolve into something else", and this has been achieved more recently through his experimentation in the studio. Techniques and instruments never before tested by RHODES have been used on some of his new tracks, allowing his music to mature and grow. Having said that, he is still keen to keep close to the place where his song-writing has always been - and still is - embedded. "For me, writing is the most important bit and it is something I have always tried to maintain as my own. A lot of artists go away and write with other people and, you know, you find out these people have written their song with big LA songwriters. For me, it detracts from any kind of integrity that a singer/songwriter has of their own and from their identity. "I think [my] songs still come from the same place and they still have that nice, natural progression. I don't think I've tried too hard to move away from what comes naturally to me. I think sometimes you can push the boundaries and end up doing something that doesn't sound like you, so I am trying to find that balance. I definitely think I've started to explore different areas a bit more... [but] I've tried to make it sound as organic as possible. [Overall], the writing has probably stayed quite true to what it was, it's just the production values that have slightly progressed and hopefully improved. [When] I was recording my first EP's at home, I didn't really know what I was doing."
Nick Mulvey was the first person I went on tour with and he's so Zen and so chilled out - you can tell he absolutely loves life. He was always meditating, which was quite weird but also so inspiring
This determination to stick to his roots is something RHODES really emphasised to me, particularly when discussing who, or what, influences him the most. "I suppose, like most people, [my inspiration comes from] love and the effect that can have on people. I mean, not only relationships (like boyfriend and girlfriend), but also family, and watching how other people fall in love. I think even from a young child I was very obsessed with love and that is something I've always thought about. I remember thinking about it from such a young age, the way I perceived it and the way, as I've grown up, I've seen the different perceptions of it - the way it can, and does, affect people as they get older, it makes people change." Considering such inspiration is so important to RHODES, it is something he strives to convey to audiences when performing. "I try to create an atmosphere with the sounds I use on my guitar to lull people down to a place where they are intently listening." Even so, he did admit it may be a little different this time round: "I suppose that... now I have a band... it is going to be about getting the energy up in the room. There will definitely still be intimate moments of the set, though, when I will speak more directly to people." Creating such an atmosphere, particularly within bigger spaces, is not an easy feat. Nonetheless, having toured with many big names, RHODES has picked up a few tips along the way. "I was touring with Ben Howard and we were playing in a big auditorium in Berlin. I was really scared, as there were so many people there, but I just thought 'I'm just going on there with my guitar, make a big sound and get everyone listening'. I think that was the easiest I've ever found it." Ben Howard wasn't the only inspiration for performance, however. Every artist who RHODES has enjoyed touring with has given him something that he has integrated into his own style. "Ben Howard was probably my most favourite person to go on tour with, as it was then that I discovered how much I like his music. I hadn't listened to him that much before... London Grammar were amazing to go on tour with, as they are really fun to hang around with, and Sam Smith was really inspirational. [caption id="attachment_121324" align="alignnone" width="640"] "To be honest, whenever anybody asks who my favourite artist was to go on tour with, all I can say is that I learnt so much from everybody and each artist gave me something different. Nick Mulvey was the first person I went on tour with and he's so Zen and so chilled out - you can tell he absolutely loves life. He was always meditating, which was quite weird but also so inspiring. Just to see the way different people take different things from life is amazing." Now heading towards summer, RHODES is not slowing down. With an album underway and singles still yet to be released, he is heading into festival season with some serious drive. Although nothing official was disclosed, RHODES did tell me that he's hoping to appear at many of the big festivals this year. He did, of course, play at Glastonbury last year, and this alternate world whet his appetite for more festival life. "It's a lot more fun [at festivals], and you get to hang out with all the other bands which is nice. It's much more of a community feel. Every festival you do, you bump into people you see on the road and you get the chance to catch up - it's really nice." So, whether you caught him on tour this time around, or you're waiting to discover him on a stage at a festival somewhere this summer, keep your eyes peeled for RHODES. His warm, acoustic vibes are hard not to enjoy and - with all the experience he has under his belt - such an atmosphere is hard to resist at a live gig. With Nick Mulvey's Zen aura and Ben Howard's ability to capture an audience in one chord, RHODES rolls these two into one rather enthralling performer - one not to be missed this year. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_RD8B_cFD4U
